message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of gravity and how it decreases as we move away from a massive object. Gravity lessens as we move away from a planet because the gravitational force exerted by the planet is stronger closer to it and weaker farther away. Option (A) is incorrect because a black hole is an extremely massive object with a strong gravitational pull, so gravity would be stronger near it. Option (C) is incorrect because gravity actually increases as we get closer to a planet. Option (D) is incorrect because although the sun has a much larger mass than a planet, the gravitational force it exerts decreases as we move away from it.

This question requires basic knowledge about gravity and its effects. Gravity is a force that pulls objects towards each other. As you move away from a planet, the gravitational force between you and the planet decreases, thus lessening the effect of gravity. Option (A) is incorrect because being alongside a black hole would actually increase the gravitational force. Option (C) is also incorrect because as you get closer to a planet, the gravitational force becomes stronger. Option (D) is incorrect because the gravitational force of the sun is much stronger than that of a planet, so gravity would actually increase as you get closer to the sun.

This question requires basic knowledge about gravity and how it works. Gravity is a force that attracts objects towards each other. As you move away from a planet, the gravitational force weakens and lessens. Option (A) is incorrect because black holes have extremely strong gravitational forces that would increase, not lessen, as you go alongside one. Option (C) is also incorrect because as you get closer to a planet, the gravitational force increases. Option (D) is incorrect because while the gravitational force from the sun is greater than that of a planet, it does not lessen as you get closer to the sun.

This question requires basic knowledge about the relationship between gravity and distance. Gravity lessens as you move away from a planet because the gravitational force exerted by the planet becomes weaker as the distance between the object and the planet increases. Option (A) is incorrect because black holes have such strong gravitational pull that gravity would actually increase as you go alongside one. Option (C) is incorrect because gravity would also increase as you get closer to a planet. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun also has a strong gravitational pull and gravity would increase as you get closer to it.

This question requires basic knowledge about the concept of gravity and how it behaves with distance. Gravity lessens as you move away from a planet. This is because gravity follows the inverse square law, which means that the gravitational force decreases as the distance between two objects increases. Option (A) is incorrect because getting closer to a black hole would actually increase the gravitational force. Option (C) is incorrect because getting closer to a planet would increase the gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because getting closer to the sun would also increase the gravitational force.

Gravity lessens as you move away from a planet because the gravitational force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two objects. Option (A) is incorrect because black holes have extremely strong gravitational forces. Option (C) is also incorrect because the gravitational force increases as you get closer to a planet. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun has a much stronger gravitational force compared to a planet.
